this bulb down here is called the

I'm going to show you my favorite
structure by flipping the brain over
like this so you can see the bottom part

very bottom of the brain is a structure

hippocampus hippocampus is critical for

allows us to learn and retain you long
term memories for thoughts and events
and before I put this down because you

I should take picture
got it okay all right yeah good answer
I'm going to keep that there so I want
to tell you about what the coolest
things about being a neuroscientist
being scientists in general what it
allows you to do is you know how
sometimes things make you go well when
you're a scientist you could actually
answer that question so I'm gonna tell
you about something that maybe go hmm
and how it kind of started a whole new
research area in my lab so this came
about not because I went to the library
and I started reading books or I went to
hear a talk I went to the gym so
neuroscientists have to stay in shape
too and I needed to get in the best
shape I wanted to get in the best shape
of my life and I went to the gym I loved
it kept me coming back and back to the
gym it's a class called intense achi
intense stands for intention and sati
means awareness so in this class we use
physical movements from kickboxing dance
and yoga and martial arts but the cool
thing is that each movement is paired
with a physical with a verbal
confirmation so in kickboxing you just
punch right and left but in intensity
would say I am strong now and the
audience or the participants say back to
you so you do that for a whole hour for
20 different moves and affirmations so I
went to the gym I started going two
three four five times a week and I was
getting stronger and I had more stamina
and it was in a great mood but you know
what else happened when I went back to
work my memory worked better I could pay
attention better I could write better I
feel like my brain is stronger
so I went to the literature and it turns
out that there all these studies showing
that if you have rats and mice run on
the running wheel you know what happens
their brains change their brains
actually get thicker the brain cells
called neurons grow more extensions and
the electrical activity in those rat and
my sprung brains get enhanced you get
more activity when you stimulate then in
the rats that were just sitting around
and not running in the environment the
most amazing thing I found was that they
found that rats running and running will
actually have more new cells born into
their brain but not in all parts of the
brain only in my favorite part of the
brain which is the hippocampus that's
right
so more new shiny new hippocampal cells
are born in your hippocampus when you
exercise I huh that must be what's
happening I'm exercising and I'm getting
more hippocampal cells but I'm a
scientist one study one person doesn't
make a whole a whole experiment so I
decided to use my students as my guinea
pigs and here's what I did so I decided
to teach a new class called can exercise
change your brain this is an NYU I work
down down the road at NYU for this I
wanted to bring exercise into the
classroom so the students could exercise
and feel the physical benefits of
exercise and then I could tell them
about what exercise could be doing to
their brains so I actually went to the
gym I got certified to teach intensity
and every single class was the power of
intensity that I taught these kids
together with an hour and a half of
lecture discussion on what exercise was
doing the semester and I asked did they
get smarter did their memories get
better compared to another class that
learned about neuroscience but didn't do
any exercise you know what happened they
got smarter my class
got significantly better on learning new
things putting new things in long-term
memory so here is the bottom line
exercise is not only good for your body
and your muscles and your heart it's
good for your brain
okay so you guys going to go and workout
